block.p: Ford Acknowledges Risks Of Sport Utility Vehicles Ford Motor, which depends on sport utility vehicles for much of its profits, acknowledged that they cause serious safety and environmental problems. Ford said that the vehicles contributed more than cars to global warming, emitted more smog-causing pollution and endangered other motorists.

Ford said that it would keep building them because they are so profitable but would seek technological solutions and look for alternatives to the big vehicles. William C. Ford Jr., the company's chairman, depicted the company's statements as a combination of altruism and long-term business planning. [Page A1.]

Increase in Foreign Workers Urged Racing to keep up with a booming economy, President Clinton proposed an increase of more than 85 percent in the number of skilled foreign workers who could be admitted to the United States to fill job openings in the high-technology industries. [A16.]

Merrill Lynch Joins the Perks Parade Merrill Lynch has joined the rush of Wall Street firms offering new perks and risk-free investment opportunities to attract young investment bankers and prevent others from defecting to Internet companies. Merrill is building a new fitness center for employees and providing a concierge service. The firm also hopes to lock in investment bankers by giving them chances to invest in new-economy companies that are still private. [C2.]

Denver Papers in Joint Agreement The Denver Rocky Mountain News announced that it intended to combine its business operations with those of The Denver Post. The agreement, which would end the nation's fiercest newspaper war, would leave the Denver area with two newspapers that would compete journalistically but split their profits. [A21.]

Stocks Climb, With Nasdaq Up 3.4% Stocks climbed after a report of a slowdown in retail sales calmed investors who have been selling stocks amid fears about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 178.19 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,545.97. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 114.85 points, or 3.4 percent, to 3,499.58, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 24.76 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,407.81. [C8.]

Profit Rises 21% at Dell Computer Dell Computer posted a 21 percent increase in first-quarter profit, beating Wall Street expectations, as it benefited from a richer mix of products, with particular strength in sales of servers and storage devices for Internet use. Before Dell reported its results, its shares closed down 25 cents, to $44.6875. After hours, Dell rose as high as $47.625. [C6.]

In Spain, Olive-Fueled Electricity In Spain, olives are being transmuted into a fuel. For the last three years, farmers around one olive-growing hamlet have delivered the residue of olive oil production to a specially designed power station, where it is burned to produce electricity, thus reducing Spain's reliance on imported oil. [C4.]

Retail Sales Dropped 0.2% in April Sales at the nation's retailers fell 0.2 percent in April, the first time in a year and a half, as consumers took a breather after three months in which they spent at the fastest rate in 17 years, government figures showed. [C5.]

Y.& R. Chief Expected to Depart Young & Rubicam's president and chief executive, Thomas D. Bell Jr., will most likely step down from the advertising agency after it is acquired by WPP Group, executives close to the negotiations said. Both companies were working to complete the deal. [C20.]
